p: Frankincense, the oleogum resin of Boswellia spp., is a multicomponent mixture containing 5–15% essential oil, 25–30% ether-insoluble compounds such as polysaccharides, and 55–66% ether-soluble pure resin, containing therapeutically interesting triterpenoids [ 1, 4]. Of particular interest are boswellic acids, which belong to the class of pentacyclic triterpenic acids and are exclusively occurring in the genus Boswellia with contents up to 25% [ 5]. Boswellic acids are also highly abundant in cambium and epidermis, where they are assumed to be synthesized from amyrins [ 6].
